meanings.definition: Given to frequent changes of mood; temperamental.
meanings.sent1: She can be quite moody, going from happy to sad in a matter of minutes.
meanings.sent2: The stormy sky looked moody, with dark clouds looming overhead.
meanings.sent3: His moody behavior made everyone unsure of how to act around him.
meanings.sent4: The old house had a moody atmosphere, as if it held many secrets within its walls.
meanings.sent5: The music had a moody melody that evoked a sense of nostalgia.

meanings.sent1: Her moody painting captured the essence of loneliness with its dark colors.
meanings.sent2: The actor's moody performance conveyed a sense of deep sorrow to the audience.
meanings.sent3: The moody poem painted a vivid picture of a rainy day in the woods.
meanings.sent4: The sunset cast a moody light over the landscape, creating a sense of tranquility.
meanings.sent5: The photographer captured the moody atmosphere of the city streets at night.

meanings.definition: A person who is given to frequent changes of mood.
meanings.sent1: She's a real moody, always changing her mind about what she wants to do.
meanings.sent2: The moody in the office can make it challenging to predict how the day will go.
meanings.sent3: The moody at the party kept everyone on their toes with their unpredictable behavior.
meanings.sent4: Being a moody can be exhausting, constantly feeling different emotions throughout the day.
meanings.sent5: The children found it amusing to watch the moody switch from laughter to tears in an instant.
